page.title: 04QUARRYING NEAR WEST HOATHLY
page.content: The massive fine grained sandstone which forms the upper part of the {Lower Tunbridge Wells Sand}is a valuable building material which has been extensively used. There are several quarries in this area but only {Philpots}is now working. Stone from the old quarry in the garden of {Selsfield House}was used in the rebuilding of{St Swithuns Church, East {Grinstead}after the steeple collapsed in{1785.}The exposed surface of the sandstone at Philpots shows broad horizontal strata with pronounced vertical joints giving massive blocks occasionally stained red with iron and blue-black with silt. Ripple marks and sun cracks can be seen and traces of calcite crystals. The stone quarried today is much used in restoring buildings, in decorative stonework and for rockeries.
